comment: He's a great professor who gave us background information about topics taught in class as well as demonstrated techniques necessary for creating websites. He always had a positive attitude in class, effective teaching methods and gave us more resources if necessary. Also very responsive! This is a professor who is above and beyond, don't miss out!
He always had a very positive attitude and energy. His lectures were informative and he gave a lot of external resources to help out. He takes you step by step through the process of web design.

I have never coded before and he made it easy by showing us step by step what to do, as well as giving us many resources. Also just loved his energy and attitude; after taking his class I want to be his friend.

Professor Aston was probably my favorite professor out of three years. I really enjoyed his lectures and he was always accessible and quick to respond. He gives amazing feedback and really cares about his students. 10/10
ratingTags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Jason is a super cool guy. He's very laid back and tells us exactly what we need to do for each point on the assignment. comment: The best professor I've had. Always available to speak with you; not one of those professors who don't read emails or messages. Haven't finished the course yet but I can already be confident in giving this rating.
ratingTags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Prof. Espinosa is an amazing professor! She cooperates to help you succeed which complements her charming personality. Overall, take her to avoid reading a textbook because she gives you the class notes with the solutions. If you want to boost your GPA, take her! You will not regret it.

comment: Professor Espinosa is very caring, dedicated, and knowledgeable. She is open to answering questions and receiving feedback. The homework is manageable, and midterms have extra credit. As a result of her good teaching and relatively lenient grading, this class is relatively easy. I highly recommend Professor Espinosa!

i really liked her as a professor but she is not very good at responding to emails. she is extremely nice during office hours and is willing to give lots of help, but the difficulty comes from the difficulty of the course, not her. although, she is a little bit stingy with giving past exam answers. professor liu gives out more material than she doe

Overall, pretty good. Standard professor. More homework than most but has clear grading standards. Goes over the material kinda fast, but is willing to slow down. Midterms were a little hard, but she's very lenient on submitting.
ratingTags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: She is very nice and helpful. Always willing to slow down the class to answer questions and provide help. Homework twice a week, overall, not difficult to manage. Extra credit on the midterms. Midterms were a little difficult but she goes over all the concepts clearly, so just pay attention to the lectures and study. She grades very fairly.
ratingTags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: She is very nice and always willing to slow down the class to a better pace. Homeworks are a little hard but are good practice for exams. I just had two midterms and a final with homeworks for my grade. She has a little accent but not that hard to understand. As long as you can get the general idea of the concepts, easy A.
The material is difficult, but she provides really detailed notes for each unit. She also genuinely cares that you understand - she is willing to stop and explain and is very accessible and nice.
Just a fun course and a fun professor. Felt more like a stand up comedian than a lecturer with all the funny stories he told during lectures.

This class is lowkey overrated. Yes, take it if you want a GPA boost that you have to work for and you are in need of a few more credits. I learned a lot from the class but you learned about things you already knew. It's like listening to a bunch of TED talks. Dan is a great speaker. But if you're into positive pysch, definitely take this class.
ratingTags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: A few people think the Science of Happiness is overrated but I'm not exaggerating when I say this class changed my life for good. Dan is an incredible storyteller and a passionate speaker - each lecture is part standup, part motivational speech. I learned so much about myself and I wish I could take this class again.

Great learning experience and presentations. Both Professors Lerner and Schlechter showed for great chemistry in their class together, evident in their positive energy in classroom atmosphere. Two five-page papers and weekly assignments are nothing to complain about, and they give great feedback. I didn't feel like copy and pasting my past review.

Took in summer session. So only weekly reflections, 2 papers, 1 group project, and a final exam. Need to take some time but the workload isnt crazy. Not a very scientifically rigorous class. A lot of chatting and useless stories. Little solid knowledge, but there are definitely some values or skills that you can take away and apply in your life.

If you want to hear someone mansplain to you how you should live this life, you should take this class. If you don't, DO NOT take this. It was a waste of time and money. It was mostly opinion based and the professors mostly talked about their own kids. It is NOT an easy A like some believe, it is a LOT of work. I hated every second of this class.

Great guy, makes lecture funny and enjoyable while still teaching you. 3 pop attendance quizzes, make sure you go to recitation and participate. "This is important"  on the final exam. Basically just do the bare minimum and you will get an A. Other than that, you will enjoy this class if you are interested in positive psych or want a GPA boost!

Dan is great! One of the best I've had at NYU, across any department. This review is for Anna Wilgan. She should not be allowed to TA at any accredited college university. She was unprofessional and vague, routinely showed up 15 minutes late to recitation, and cares only about keeping the majority of students in the "B" range. Bad look for NYU.
ratingTags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational

comment: Such a great professor. One of the best I have ever had. The class flies by when he is teaching, and he makes class entertaining and relatable. I loved having him.

The first thing Dan and Alan do is acknowledge the students in their class.  They bring this element of humanity into the classroom that I haven't seen anywhere else in college. The course is essentially Positive Psychology 101, and if you're into that (as I am) you'll eat this class up and wish there was more. Dan is an amazing teacher and person.

Dan is so funny! He talks about his son a lot so the lectures are very personal (worth going). There are 3 pop attendance checks and also during lecture, when he says "that's important" - it's on the test. There is only one final exam and no set apart review session. He is ready to talk after class about life or course material!

One of the best professors and humans I've ever met. Dan is SO passionate about what he does and it shows. Lectures were seriously a blast, I laughed so hard I cried countless times and was inspired even more. You learn a lot of valuable info/skills in Science of Happiness. I couldn't recommend this class more.
Best professor. Best class
Good Lecture, He and Alan are perfect together teaching this class.

Professor Fotsch was pretty good overall. No hw and the online class had 2 oral tests, a final (another oral test), and a paper. The oral exams were basically open notes and you get the questions before hand with a review. He's a pretty fair grader. Lectures are super boring, scared for how much harder his class will be in person.

I took Prof Fotsch for Intro to Media studies during J-Term and I could not have asked for a better teacher. Everyone stressed me out about attempting a J-Term but with him it was easy! Def stay in his class. I wrote the paper the day before it was due and did well. I'm taking him again for MCC3 so I'll update this review at the end of the semester
ratingTags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things

comment: super intelligent and one of the kindest professors at NYU. take him!

Paul is a great teacher, very funny which helps you stay focused and pay attention. He doesn't really have a grading rubric so it's hard to know what to do to get an A, but overall a great course. Make sure to do the readings. Great teacher, love him!

Paul is very humorous and can keep your attention in class. However, his grading seems arbitrary. I would ask him for feedback on papers/exams, make the changes he suggested, and still received a grade that made it seem like I didn't do anything. He can be unclear with what he wants. He also assigns A LOT of reading.

A's are rare, do not expect any surprises at the end of the semester. Grading on exams seems somewhat arbitrary, hard to understand exactly what is wanted. The class is humorous and will keep your attention, it's based on participation and personal examples. I would take the class again and try to expand on the exams, I think an A is possible.

Really cool, funny. Engaging, lots of class discussion. No homeworks. Readings for every class, DO THEM (they are fun too). 2 Midterms, 1 Final. He gives you 4 essay prompts based on the reading 2 weeks prior to each exam and can ask any one of them. No word limit or specifications. One final term paper, also super fun+easy. Definitely take him.

He is a great professor!! So funny and we always had great class discussions. HIs tests are easy, he gives the questions beforehand. One paper-it was an interesting one though! Loved having him! Take him for Intro To Human Comm.

he's quirky but he's awesome! take him for intro to human comm! he's pretty easy and you don't have to read all the articles.  he definitely knows what he's talking about and is very knowledgeable.  friendly and is willing to offer help outside of office hours. loved having him !

TAKE HIM!!! had for hist of media, gives you essay questions before the exam and then chooses one...class is sometimes boring but he tries his hardest to make the material interesting. as long as you pay attention and occasionally do some of the reading you will get an a. hes also really nice and randomly funny

Has for intro to media studies. Takes attendence EVERY  lecture which means you can't really skip cuz its part of your grade. Not too hard of a grader,but you have to be very detailed. Midterms and finals are explaining 2 terms, so most of the stuff your learn in lecture is useless for the tests. Pretty interesting class tho

The class could get boring at times, but overall he tried (and was usually able to) facilitate a good discussion and explain the sometimes-murky readings. He's a pretty likable and quirky guy, and he was able to make the class as fun as it could be.

Took Senior Media Seminar with Fotsch, who is a new professor at NYU. Very nice guy, who is surprisingly random/quirky/funny, but even that can't make up for the fact that the class is 2.5 hours long and ultimately pretty boring. Like the professor, hate the class.

She's so nice and the assignments are super easy as long as you're willing to talk about something personal or important to you. For the second LS writing class, we only wrote 1 essay :) Take her you won't regret it and might even make a friend!

Just show up, talk a little bit, and make it seem like you care about your essays and you'll get an A. She's a bit unorganized and gets off topic during class, but it's worth writing 3 Essays that you can just pull out of your ass and still get an A for.

One of my favorite professors at NYU. She is very kind and the class is an easy A as long as you occasionally participate and put at least some effort into the assignments. She likes classroom discussions and she makes the class very fun and interesting.

She's a really nice and sweet person but beware you will have to share a lot of personal details on essays and in-class (but if you do you'll get an A). The assignments can be a bit tedious and pointless at times but it's worth it to become a better writer.

Listen, if you're extroverted you will LOVE Dr. Steinmetz. I loved the essays that we wrote since they focused on personal stories, making them stress-free. Downsides for some people is that she will sometimes call you out even if you don't raise your hand; also LOVES breakout rooms. However, She can be a bit unorganized at times. Moderate reading.
easy course with caring teacher, though didn't get much feedback on essays.
Take her!! She is so caring and always willing to support you. Very easy grader and our entire class loved her. Understanding. She's amazing!

She will make you a better writer, but I dont agree with her methods of teaching. She will constantly try and create prompts that force students to reveal trauma- ill never forget when she forced a student to tell his entire coming out story to the class- and when he stopped talking she finished the story for him revealing tons of personal info
ratingTags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Super sweet and understanding prof. does not take much effort to get at least A-. I don't think your writing will improve significantly, but you learn diff styles of writing. hw was def manageable. you do need to participate but she makes it pretty easy. you write a couple drafts for each paper. vague prompts, but grades easily

Prof. Steinmetz is good. She makes you hand in multiple drafts of each essay which is a bit annoying. But she helps you revise each draft both with her and peers and ultimately youll write papers that you are proud of. She does require participation and sometimes cold calls which is annoying but her class is good.

I've had many caring and enthusiastic teachers over my years of education, but I've never had anyone like Dr. Steinmetz. Please take her for Writing I, you will not regret it. She is the most caring, flexible, and open-minded professor you can have. There are readings she asks you to do, but this class is an easy A; however, you still learn a lot.

Professor Steinmetz is an absolute gem in the Liberal Studies department at NYU. She is inspirational, caring, kind, and incredibly helpful. She absolutely taught me to be a better writer this semester, and I wish I could take her again and again. Her feedback has been invaluable to my writing, and you should DEFINITELY take her if you can.

I'm really sad I can't take Dr. Steinmetz for Writing II. She's an excellent professor who really cares about her students work and well being. She's been especially accommodating during the Covid-19 circumstances and is very aware of her students needs. She's extremely available outside of class either for classwork or just to talk in general.

I really had an incredible time in Steinmetz's class, I am so sad that I can't take her for Writing II. She's really nice and an amazing professor, her class had that small intimate high school feel. Show up to class, participate, and do SOME of the readings and you'll get an A easily.
ratingTags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: shes such a good professor. im so sad I wont be able to take her again for writing II. loved going to her class - it didnt seem like a writing class, theres 3 essays and one group presentation - all super easy. shes an easy grader. only con is that she lets you write about whatever you want so theres no specific instructions/guidance.

comment: Her class isn't hard, it's actually a lot of fun. I love going to her class everyday. She's hilarious and super woke. Her essay prompts are vague but that gives you room to free write. Her class is based on culture a lot so if ur comfortable writing about that then take her. I didn't learn much about how to be a better writer, but essays were fun.

If you want a teacher who is nice and an easy A, then yeah take her. But if you're looking to improve your writing and receive good feedback, then look for somebody else. There's been times that I wrote my paper half asleep, never revised it, and she still gave me an A with no feedback. She goes on weird random tangents too. Nice, but useless.
I love Dr. Steinmetz. She's really funny and genuinely cares for her students.

Amazing Professor, truly cares about students and passionate about English. Took her Writing I class loved it so much taking Writing II. Try and you will do well, always there to help. Easy good grade with some class participation, attendance is important.
ratingTags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Would take again

comment: Really easy grader, assigns interesting readings and makes you go on field trips to the Met. Participation not necessary to get an A, cares about all her students.

Dr. Steinmetz's class can be engaging and fun, and the papers are relatively easy if you know what she's looking for. The problem is you usually won't. She definitely cares and wants her students to do well, but the assignments are so unclear it'll take a lot of office hours and 2-3 drafts (thankfully she allows them) before you can.

Dr. Steinmetz is so great. I really enjoyed coming to her class because she's such a sweet and relatable person. A lot of people didn't care for her because her assignments for papers were very vague, but I thought she just left it open to interpretation. You don't learn a lot about how to write though, you learn a few strategies but thats it.
very open-minded and truly cares about the students. manageable reading loads and more revision-heavy with fewer essays

She lacks clarity in prompts for her essays, and this stressed me all the time because writing is NOT my strong suit. But nevertheless they were interesting. She loves teaching and reading our work. She tries her best to help us improve, and get to know us. I think if you had the chance to take her class, in the end, you will not be disappointed.
I could not recommend this teacher.  She is not supportive and she lacks clarity.   I would best say she is out of touch with her students.  Highly recommend not taking.

At first I thought Steinmetz was going to be a good professor,but that soon changed.While her prompts are vague,she expects your writing not to be vague.When I went for help she didn't help at all.She has a very strict no late work policy, and won't accept any late work at all.She also gets upset easily if the class doesn't participate right away.

I loved having Professor Steinmetz as a Writing II instructor. She is truly passionate about what she does and wants nothing more than to see her students grow and flourish as writers. Oh, and her puns and comparisons are hilariously wonderful. Highly recommend.

Dr. Steinmetz was the single most influential person on me as a writer. She is the most personable and caring instructor one could ask for. As long as you keep up with assignments, and stay active in class, there's no reason you won't get a good grade. Her essays have vague prompts, but she encourages a lot of personality in your writing.
She is the best professor at NYU that I have ever encountered.

Dr. Steinmetz is the best. The books she has us read are very helpful, and she is very clear with what she wants in the essays. She gives students alot of freedom in choosing essay topics, which is good. If you want to transform your writing, definitely take this class!
easy grader but not very helpful

So easy its not even fair. Sweet professor. She goes over a lot of concrete basics in writing. At times it felt like her templates were so restricting and childish it got a little annoying but you have a good amount of say and freedom and in the end - a good essay. I barely put any effort in - just do the assignments and show up and talk.
Great professor- funny and helpful. Passionate about writing. Mandatory attendance.
Very helpful in class, she knows how to teach and is very helpful.  Attendance is mandatory in class, but otherwise, she is a great writing teacher.

I don't love core classes (because I don't love reading aha) but Prof Andermann is such a genuinely caring professor who wants the best for his students and is also so passionate about the subject he teaches. Although I really couldn't care less about the content of the class, I'd definitely take this professor again!

Jens obviously really cares about what he is teaching and it's clear that he wants to help you learn. We watched pre-recorded lectures before each class, which we had quizzes on afterwards for participation credit, and those could be kind of tough but not bad overall. Take a ton of notes on the pre-recorded lectures and you'll be fine.

Definitely have to pay attention to lectures to get all the necessary details for the quizzes and final, but overall, Professor Andermann is really sweet and clearly passionate about his class. Decent number of readings, but there's no essays, just a few discussion posts and short quizzes before the final.

Ngl the class itself was really boring but I only showed up because Andermann is such a sweet person. Participation is 20% of the grade. No papers, just 5 small forums on nyu classes which is 25% Show up, do the readings and you will be fine. Midterm & Final was just a regurgitation of what he said in lecture. would take HIM again but not the class
unclear grading for the whole semester. Hard to follow his lecture. Super easy exams so you have to get full mark to get an A.
He comes unprepared, his lectures are messy and he is not approachable.

As an instructor, he's not always the most clear in the classroom, but is pretty much always willing to go over what you don't know, as long as you admit that you don't know. Our class got a bit vocal about what was fair to test and what was unfair and he actually took it pretty well.
ratingTags: Inspirational--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: The professor is famous, but he is not a good instructor since he does not know how to teach. He emphasises a lot that he is a professor but not a teacher and he will not teach again the knowledge he talked in class during the office hours. He is conceited. The lectures were unstructured and his calculation made everyone confused.

He is a very approachable and makes lectures entertaining and interesting. Very intelligent guy and expects his students to atleast read the material beforehand (which you should, cumon this IS math). As for all the negative comments, he has improved considerably and is very passionate about what he teaches.

Lectures are entertaining, but don't expect to get much actual knowledge from them. His TAs were a mixed bag. One was fair, the other was completely lazy and did not even grade the assignments, he just assigned some grade and gave you back the assignment without a mark on it. NYU has a very, very bad set of math TAs, for the most part.

Lectures remind a random walk over the topics. Often doesn't slow down on difficult moments and avoids complete proofs. The good way to go through his course is to read the topics beforehand. Get a set of good books: Shreve, Oksendal. Get ready to spend a lot of time solving homework problems. Don't miss problem sessions. His TA's are fair graders.

Pretty good if you come to class having looked at the material beforehand, otherwise you will probably be totally lost. Overall, he's a nice guy, althoughy he can be testy during his office hours, and he gives easy problem sets.
No Comments

Awful, absolutely positively AWFUL! The worst professor ever. He showed up late everyday, and it took him an entire semester to teach not even half of the calculus material we need to know to move to Calc 2. RETARD!

If you have no calc background good luck. He speaks with a heavy italian accent and writes like he is 5. The class is generally large so if you dont hear/understand him the first time (which you wont) you will have a hell of a semester playing catch up
No Comments
She is an engaging speaker, a lovely person, and clear with exams and directions. Overall, I greatly enjoyed her lectures!
An energetic, smart, and engaging teacher.  I highly recommend her! Best ITS teacher :)

She's brilliant, she's generous, and she guides discussion very well. This is my second class with her, which should say something. An incredible human being, capable of actually being friend while she's still your teacher.

Always willing to give of herself and her personal time in order to help help students, make them understand, and help them grow. The most resounding praise is the fact that about 75% of my class has taken her as a teach before and loved her enough to take her again. She rocks! And it doesn't hurt that she's easily one of the hottest profs at NYU.

karmen is a blast. she's fun, perky, good humored, and very intelligent. she has an interesting spin on some standard plays she goes over in the course that make them almost new. she's also TOTALLY hot and wears some bangin clothes. A+
Karmen rocks! Totally adorable. Strives to make class enthralling and succeeds. A wonderful teacher, amazing human being, and total hottie!

Prof. O is the best professor I met at Stern. I had him for orgcom. He is very knowledgeable in the field of business communication . I found all his lectures and the cases we studied very interesting. I started the class just thinking of it as a requirement to graduate but it has been my favorite course in college so far. Def recommend him!

This class was overall extremely useful! I think I really learned how to better carry myself as a professional, both as a presenter, and through email. Prof O. always gave good feedback, and taught us to use "memo" format in our emails which made us seem more professional. There are occasional readings to do before class and lots of presentations.
Too harsh of a grader. Too strict. Not fun

comment: Seem's like a very nice person, however the way she grades is very tough and can feel contrived. Seems to purposefully not want to give an A.
ratingTags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Tough grader

comment: This professor seems to live for the moment she can return your work to you and throw incredible amounts of negative comments and harsh words in there. Absolutely never gives constructive criticism. Be ready to work your butt off for a 75 and a "I'm guessing you aren't reading the material or you just can't understand it."

I was very excited for this class but it led to GREAT disappointment. She believes we have all the time in the world for this class and drowned us in TONS of assignments. We did the best we could for group projects but all she gave was harsh critics and low grades. It's hard to understand what she is thinking. Just terrible!!!

I really enjoyed this class, except for the group work & presentations. A lot of reading & analysis' on the readings, writing, group/case work, & class participation. No exams. I prefer papers over exams. She allows you to resubmit work for a better grade, but be on time. Her grading is tough to figure out. But overall great Prof.
ratingTags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Lots of group work. Class participation requires well thought out answers and analysis. Be prepared to work for our grade

I took WTE (as my first college writing course) and Prof Tadmor was wonderful. There's 3 essays, where a full draft is due a week in advance, but she gives all the feedback to improve + conferences. She pushes deadlines so you have enough time to write & revise. There are usually 2 readings per essay but they're easy. Make sure you're on time!

I had Professor Tadmor for Writing the Essay and she is simply the sweetest soul. Make sure you always put your best in the drafts because her feedback off off your drafts will be THE ONLY feedback you get, but if you use those changes you new guaranteed an A. She is super understanding and often gave us extensions for our 3 essays. Such a gem.

This was a very difficult class. Avia grades very hard. The three writing assignments were basically chosen for you (societal issues) which made the class dreadful and a drag to write any of the papers. She wants a final draft level paper a week before you submit it. She also is very strict with attendance and you have to arrive 5 minutes early.
ratingTags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Prof Tadmor is honestly the best. It's clear that she really cares about her students and is extremely passionate about writing. She's super organized and really teaches her students how to get better at writing. Prof Tadmor is also really understanding when it comes to the classes workload and often times gives extensions on papers.

The writing professor everyone should have. She is incredibly sweet and caring (How is it possible for a human to be this nice?), and has a true passion for writing that shines through in her classes. She takes into account different previous experiences with writing and is always willing to talk your ideas out with you to help you grow as a writer

Prof Brewer has 5 TA's who do all the grading, usually 4 essays and 5 quizzes (but it's an easy A). Essays are usually based on reading, which can be skimmed but on personal opinion and the grading isn't strict. Extensions were given on everything but use your time wisely. Take this class if you need credit and an easy A (with some effort)!

This is the class that made me realize I want to minor in education, thanks to Prof. Brewer. He is very passionate and inspirational, and clearly always knows what he's doing. Over Brightspace, it was an easy A because 40% of the grade was quizzes that you can take 10 times (easy 100%) and 60% was papers that you can't really go wrong with.

Cath is a GEM. Just show up and participate, and you will get an A. There's no quizzes/tests or essays  just project (group or solo) and very easy homework (where you need to take a photo that connects with class explaining and upload). Only thing is her instructions or grading is unclear, but just ask and she clarifies. THE SWEETEST PROFESSOR!!!

Professor Milne is passionate about the content that she teaches - she always has a bright attitude towards her students. There's MINIMAL homework, NO tests, nothing you would expect from a typical science course. If you don't participate your grade will definitely suffer, but if you show up and say one thing per class you'll be absolutely fine.

Cath is such an understanding and great professor and I thoroughly enjoyed her class. She doesn't give tests /quizzes, she just wants you to show up to class and learn. I wish I had more professors like her!
ratingTags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: Cath is so funny and eccentric, and she just wants students to try. If you raise your hand to answer one question each class you'll be fine. There are weekly snaplog assignments due and a few other projects assigned here and there. If you do the homeworks and the (middle school level) experiments in class, you'll pass without a doubt.
Attendance is very important to her, even though I participated, knew all the material and performed well on assessments, my grade was docked down to a B because of attendance

While taking her class, I thought I was in a middle school science class. A lot of hands-on experiments, but they're fun sometimes. She seems passionate about what she teaches. As long as you do all the work with effort, it's not hard to get an A.

By far one of the most ridiculous professors I've had at NYU. She doesn't hand back grades but it doesn't matter because she gives everyone a B on the midterm "so we have room for improvement". Unreasonably strict on attendance (ex: didn't accept that a girl in my class had a concussion, with a doctor's note). Avoid at all costs!

Science in the Community was a great class. You can tell that Cath is very passionate about the work she does and wants to share that with all her students through a series of experiments that will engage you and make you think deeper about science. Very easy course. Participation matters. Attendance matters. COMPLETE ALL ASSIGNMENTS!!

So in this class, there was no homework, no notes that were necessary, no tests, no textbook. Entirely based off little experiments we would do in class with apples and candles and random objects like that. However, this stresses a lot of the grade to be participation based, so be careful with attendance.
lots of homework

comment: Professor Tanaka is very nice and she really does want the best for her students. Her class isn't easy though. You do have to put in a good amount of effort to come out with a good grade, and you'll also need to participate a lot. Still, she's a very solid choice.

Professor Tanaka is a solid choice for Business and Society. You are graded on three papers which increase in weightage, so you can bounce back from a poor Essay 1 score. Journals are due every Sunday, and take about 30 minutes. If you want to do well in this class, PARTICIPATE, and READ THE RUBRIC. She expects students to follow her instructions.

Professor Tanaka is great- she teaches you a lot and really helps you improve your writing. Participate in class and make sure to go to office hours. She is there to guide you through the essay process and you will succeed as long as you participate, work hard, and communicate with her. Use her feedback and incorporate it into your papers!

comment: She is terrible. Will not give you an A.

Professor Tanaka was great. Kept the focus of the class on how to incorporate the material into your papers. Make sure you participate. She'll also meet with you a week before your paper is due and will tell you exactly what to write and if you listen to that you'll do fine. Just a little tough grader in the end, very few will get an A.
ratingTags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Tanaka is one my least favorite professors at all of NYU. She plays favorites and does NOT care for her students equally. Her feedback is not constructive and there is no room for growth. I still dread taking that class.
ratingTags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Tanaka really expects you to write exactly what she wants although she is NOT explicit at all about what she wants. On the very first day, you can tell who her favourites are and who are not. And you can clearly see that bias especially through her grading and lack of constructive feedback. Good luck w getting a good grade if she doesn't love you!

Professor Tanaka is without a doubt the most caring professor I've ever encountered. While C&C entails a lot of work, will really help you through the course and make sure you do well. She really makes you work for your grade but she will be there throughout the way to guide you. You will come out of this course a much better writer and thinker.
ratingTags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Amazing teacher. She makes her class genuinely interesting. Very clear on what she wants in her papers, and gives a lot of assistance in writing them. Follow her guidelines, go to class, start your papers early: you're set.

Took her for Commerce&Culture. Not hard, but really looks for participation since most of the class is discussion. Her essays aren't hard, just consult with her prior to each one. She's really just looking for the way you think and if you can make a solid argument. Most of the time she'll tell you what she's looking for in the essay process.
ratingTags: Respected--Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: Expects you to write exactly what she wants, even if she doesn't tell you to do so. It's also obvious that she has some favorites in the class. So just be prepared to write about what she is thinking of. No room for creative expansion or personal growth or improvement in writting assignments
ratingTags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Prof. Tanaka is extremely prescriptive in her writing assignments and expects students to follow her exact guidelines when drafting essays. Depending on what kind of student you are, this can either be a blessing or a curse. Just be ready to follow orders exactly if you want to get an A in this class.
Great professor. Really specific on what she wants to see in papers and assignments. Participate and do your writing assignments and you'll pass with flying colors.

Really great guy. A lot of us in the class was amused + engaged by him and his class. Definitely made me look at theatre differently as a freshman. Not all readings were great, though. Any reading he assigned that wasn't a play was extra long and boring. He had to introduce us to lots of play genres, but I only liked half. Classfun. HWboooring

She's super friendly and is always happy to practice Chinese with you. Ngl its kinda scary to join class early bc she tries to make you practice Chinese with her, but its good for the long run. Amazing professor, but you have to work for your grade. She does give leniency especially if she sees you are putting in the effort! 10/10 professor.
ratingTags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: She genuinely cares about every one of the students and loves to joke around. Regarding one comment about her talking about student's personal lives, she just likes to get to know her students, it's not weird. She's totally accessible, understanding, and she'll make time for you any time of day (even the night before an exam!) Great teacher!

Despite the difficulty of learning online, Professor. Liu will make sure that you understand the content learnt in class. There is homework due almost every single day, but this is the same for all Chinese classes - from past experience I would even say her workload is less than other professors. Definitely recommend.

Ms Liu is a wonderful Chinese teacher. She has a great understanding of not only Chinese language but also the culture. She will interlace the lecture with relevant Chinese discussions about history and current events further adding to the teaching. She also has a great sense of humor.

There is a quiz every single day, tests every week on each chapter, and interactive homework (listening & reading comprehension) every night. Please avoid this class. This teacher shows favoritism towards specific students and inappropriately embarrasses those who are struggling. She has asked inappropriate questions about students personal life
ratingTags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Test heavy

comment: Professor Liu is the best chinese professor at NYU, she is incredibly caring, nice, and entertaining. She is really willing to go out of your way to help you out, and I highly reccomend taking her.

Prof Handschuh has invaluable experience in the industry and shares every ounce, warts and all, to the class. He is also incredibly nice and approachable even after the transition to remote learning, and genuinely cares about his students. He made what should have been an impossible transition to online learning very seamless.

Most of my professors had no idea what they were doing online and had zero appreciation of the stress that students were under this semester, as we moved home or into quarantine. David was understanding, flexible and went out of his way for individual online meetings with students and he helped us make our way through the new version of college

There's a quip a minute as Professor Handschuh does his standup in front of the class, but what you don't realize is how much you are learning about Journalism, Photojournalism,  the business of Journalism and the continuing need to keep up with the technology. David  truly cares about the students and you'd be fortunate to get into his class.

I had Prof. Handschuh for Photojournalism almost nine years ago.  I'm now working full time as a journalist and looking back at his class, I realized:1-He told and taught us things that NO other professor in ANY journalism class brought up for discussion and2-He was spot on, 100 percent RIGHT on his assessment of Journalism as a career.THANKS David

Professor Handschuh is a caring, entertaining and informative educator.  While the class is Photojournalism, he teaches about the business of photojournalism and emotional care for journalists and how to market yourself as a photographer or writer and this is really valuable information.  Highly recommended class!
Brought good resources into the class from being a photojournalist, but judging by his effort this is clearly his side job. Means well but I was definitely expecting more guidance.
I was expecting more?

Professor Handschuh is a real working journalist and his classroom lectures have helped me understand the world of journalism in ways that no other instructor have in four years of college.  He has a great sense of humor and really can teach his students how to be a better journalist and photojournalist.

Great teacher, but tough grader. Very helpful in explaining professional guidlines, clearly loves to teach others about photography. Decent sense of humor. Good class. Be prepared to take LOTS of pictures.
Really cares about his students.  Great practical advice for journalism students, not just photojournalism.  One of the best professors I've had at NYU.

She's everything you hope for in your first acting teacher. Bases her class on actual text/technique on which to build. Caring and insightful in her tutelage of each and every student who is wiling to learn. If you take the craft seriously, she's the one for you. If not, the teacher isn't the problem. It's you who isn't ready to be vulnerable.

Very maternal and supportive, regardless of your amount of experience in acting. I would recommend her, but don't be afraid to ask for further instructions: sometimes her instruction for assignments are very confusing.

Rae is one of the Performance Strategies teachers, and she's an actual actress. She really knows about acting and directing actors. She's upbeat, open, and she tries to make us let loose our emotions while acting. She's awesome

Great professor, the content is hard but his lectures definitely help you understand the material. Don't be afraid of his office hours and study more from his notes than the textbook, I did the opposite and struggled on some of the test questions which were similar to his practice problems. All in all make sure you work through problems slowly

Halpin is so great, he cares so much about his students and makes the class 100% manageable if you put in the work that he is putting in. he's lectures are very straightforward, I found I could read a text book in an hour and not understand something then have him explain it in a minute. really made me love chem by the end. what a winner

Attend lecture, do lots of practice problems, and make sure you get the concepts. You'll work a lot to do well, but he's flexible with his point system--will drop your lowest exam if you show marked improvement. He throws in some pretty funny quips in the otherwise tiring morning lecture. Overall do your best, chem is hard, he makes it a lil better

For Gen Chem II, he has been giving tougher questions on the quizzes, which we only have 10 minutes to complete. There's also not enough practice material to prepare you for the unexpected questions on his exams. Also very inaccessible, with short time slots for office hours and doesn't respond to email. Great lecturer though.

Prof Halpin was an absolutely amazing Gen Chem professor. He found a way to make learning chemistry easy and exciting. His lectures were filled with incredible examples and explanations of some complex topics. His class is structured in a way to help all students succeed by giving them the resources they need.
ratingTags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: He is excellent at explaining hard processes. He is strict though and wants an even distribution of grades (he doesn't want everyone to get As he wants us to really work for it). His exams are very hard especially the 2nd midterm. Make sure you study weeks in advance for the exams. And you have to listen to the lectures closely.
ratingTags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: despite the pandemic, Halpin changed NOTHING from last years curriculum. he is a slow lecturer, probably wont answer your question, is extremely inaccessible, etc etc etc. He does NOT curve or drop finals. lied about the content of his tests, saying it wouldnt be math heavy, since he couldnt give partial credit (Spoiler: there was)
ratingTags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Halpin is an absolutely amazing professor. His lectures are straightforward and informative. Chemistry, and his quizzes/tests, can be kind of hard though and you are given a truly massive amount of homework, especially when Lab is considered. Halpin is still awesome and super forgiving and he can be really funny. Awesome dude.

Hes probably one of the best lecturers Ive ever had. Make sure to always come to class or watch the recording cuz he tests mostly on what he said, not the textbook. Hes definitely not easy but super fair and makes you work hard.

Chemistry is just a very hard subject overall but the lectures were not very easy and he doesnt like answering questions himself. Instead he has his student teacher answer the questions. He seems to just turn on the mic to read off his notes and then log off. Theres no other way to take this chem class without him though.
ratingTags: Test heavy--Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Halpin is a gem. He cares about his students and actually lectures really well. If you work hard enough and try, it's not hard to do well in this class. Very helpful if you are struggling and go to his office hours. I'm so glad I took his course.
He really showed up and showed out for us at the end. Thank you Halpin, God bless.
ratingTags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: Gen Chem I and II will seem easy if you have taken AP Chem n high school. However, I found myself struggling with a lot of the material in the course. Make sure you buy his lecture notes, as the practice problems on exams often come from those places. His extra accommodations for covid-19, such as the 50 pt curve on the final, were appreciated.

corona had us going home and he was super understanding and reasonable about hw and attending online lectures and even cancelled one of midterms and gave us a 50pt handicap on the final. great lecturer and he truly is passionate about chemistry and cares about his students (esp ones that struggle a lot w chem like me). best chem prof!

Gen Chem sounds hard at first but its really not that bad. The material is super clear and pretty straightforward. If you took chemistry in high school you'll be fine because it felt like a repeat of that. the only bad thing is the lectures are super boring and at 8am so I stopped going. if you want to ace this class just TAKE THE PRACTICE TESTS

Halpin was just the person that administered exams and quizzes for me. Bad lecturer, class of 500+ students, limited accessibility. You are better off learning on your own by reading the textbook and asking TA's for help. Some students like/ enjoy his lectures but I stopped attending lectures after the first two weeks on Gen Chem I. Waste of time.
ratingTags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Average professor. He's clear enough for you to learn the material, but is monotone at times so it's hard to stay awake at 8 am. His lecture is almost verbatim the lecture notes. For the exams, read the textbook, do the exam practice equations.

Professor Halpin is generally a good professor. His lecture notes are clear. He goes over things in moderate speed. But he often falls back in schedule, and you might need to self-learn some concepts, although he won't put untaught calculations in exam. The class is also at 8:00 am, which is relatively early.

Lectures are EARLY, monotonous, and if you get lost, there is little to no time to ask questions (500+ students). He doesn't TEACH chemistry, he just reads from his notes (not knowing if you took HS Chem 2 or 10 years ago - postbaccs beware!) and tells you to ask your recitation prof. The exam grades were really poor b/c he teaches poorly.

I don't know why Prof. Halpin is so popular. He doesn't believe in "distance learning," which somehow justifies making us buy his lecture notes. I find his explanations conceptually lacking, and the class topics are poorly organized. Plus there's useless rote memorization. If I wasn't already familiar with the material, I would be doing terribly.
ratingTags: Test heavy--Clear grading criteria--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: This class is massive. Halpin is a great professor who is there because he genuinely cares about his students. He does not respond to emails unless you talk to him personally and he tells you too. Has plenty of office hours. The homework is completion and the quiz is out of ten points. Midterms can be tough, but he removes one of them each semester
ratingTags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: Great prof who wants his students to succeed. Attend lecture, do not fall behind and stay ahead of what he is teaching. He might seem cutthroat in the beginning but he is great and go to his office hours and work with him. Chem can be tough at times but if you put in the effort and learn how he teaches the class, it won't be too bad.

he explains material super well and wants you to succeed! he is very acessible outside of class and helps break down complicated chemistry. this class forces you understand the concepts behind chemistry instead of just memorizing how to solve problems.

Professor Halpin is very caring and drops one of your tests (including the final), but last semester decided to make us self-teach ourselves 2 chapters of chemistry. I took this class confident that I could finally do well in chemistry (I've always hated it), but this just made me struggle more in the final as I didn't understand anything.

This year, Professor Halpin thought it would be okay to not teach 2 chapters and make us self-teach ourselves. He would also lie to us about the coverage of each exam. Most people LOVE this professor, however I think he's mediocre. The only reason I did well was because I taught myself most of the material. However, he is VERY detailed/good lecture
ratingTags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Tough class, lots of homework, over 20 questions a week, ask questions go to his office hours, Im afraid to but I should go!
ratingTags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: This man is a god. For all you freshman out there, do not fret, this man is a lovable bear on this inside even though he seems cutthroat. He'll make you love chemistry. Do all the homework and practice exams (UNDERSTAND the problem, don't copy formulas), and this class is an easy A. Lab was more tedious honestly.

The key is to attend lecture! Tbh, I didn't because I figured out that as long as you click in once before 9:15, you're present. But his explanations and examples are important. Do the homework, DO THE PRACTICE TESTS, go to his review sessions. I had a really hard time, but he wants you to learn. Great guy, just be ready to work for your grade!
ratingTags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Caring

comment: He's amazing. Although it's really easy to skip the lectures, they're worth going to because Halpin's great at explaining the material.
Best Professor, great teacher!

Teaches both Gen Chem I and II, so you'll probably have him for both semesters. First semester, I didn't like the class at all and struggled really hard, but that's honestly because I'm not that good at chem. As long as you really put the effort in and realize that he REALLY just wants you to learn, you'll do fine.
He was really good.

I think this goes without saying, but you absolutely HAVE to study and put in a lot of your own work if you want to succeed in this class. Especially if you haven't taken AP Chem. Halpin was pretty good about facilitating that, and he gave you everything you needed to know. That doesn't mean he's an easy A. You'll need to do a lot more on your own.
If you pay attention in class, there is a high likelihood that you'll get a good grade. Explains concepts well and grading policy is fair.
ratingTags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Would take again

comment: Our class textbook is word for word what he says in lecture. You can nod off during class and won't miss out on too much. He has a clear lecture style and is a pretty funny guy. The exams are pretty lenient - as long as you show understanding, you will get partial to full credit. Homework is a lot but isn't a big deal as long as your TA is chill.

Halpin is my man. By far my favorite professor this semester. He explains things so well and doesn't go fast in lecture. The tests test your concepts, so you have to memorize nearly nothing. And they're pretty easy as long as you go over the practice exam. I hope I get professors like him in the future, I cant say enough good things about him.
Great professor! I learned a lot in his class. Definitely recommended.

John Halpin is one of the worst professors in the chemistry department. He reads word-for-word off a pdf during lectures. His homework assignments are ridiculously tedious (30 problems a week). Overall, he wastes a ton of time on stupid stuff like writing an extended essay on significant figures. I recommend taking chemistry at Tandon.
ratingTags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: General Chemistry is a very heavy class that requires at least triple the amount of time and effort of your average class at NYU. His quizzes are tricky, but the midterms are OK. I am not premed, so taking this class was a mistake, but I am learning a lot more than I did in High School chemistry. The class isn't that difficult, just A LOT of work.
ratingTags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria

comment: Very nice and caring. I definitely recommend Halpin! A great professor but definitely have to work hard to get A in his class. Lectures are fine as long as you pay attention and do homework.

honestly a very straightforward prof, about grading, exams, etc. lectures are kind of unnecessary, textbook is p good and he provides notes anyway.  quizzes make a difference, so actually try for those. repetition and practice are key in his class, do all problems provided - he models his questions off of other ones previously asked.
Took Halpin's gen chem sequence two semesters in a row. The man is a legend. Highly recommended!

Halpin's a clear explain and also understands that in Chem101 we mainly care about grades and getting a foundation for harder stuff and does teach to that. That being said, he also takes its status as a weed-out class seriously, with time-consuming homework and tricky test questions (go for partial credit!) It's an easy pass, but not an easy A.

Halpin as a person is fair and kind, but his lectures are unbearably boring and the course is not structured well (in my opinion). The lecture is an 8am, which makes it hard to learn for anyone who is just not a "morning person". You attend 5 classes per week for this one course. Very heavy homework (with lab), quizzes every week, difficult exams.
ratingTags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria

comment: Best professor ever.  Lectures are very easy to follow along. Course is designed in a way to prevent falling behind due to regular quizzes and homeworks assigned. Wish other science professor were half as good as Professor Halpin
Nice person and best lecturer I've had at NYU. Iconic
Legend. Taking him again for Gen Chem II next semester. If you're pre-med or interested in chemistry, he is amazing!

Wonderful lecturer. Fair grader. Tests for deep understanding. Halpin's Gen Chem course could be as insightful as it sets out to be, but has one major flaw: it drowns you in busy work (eg essays, irrelevant labs), wasting time that you could otherwise spend fortifying knowledge. As such, this is a course on time management more than anything else.

Incredible prof! Thoroughly knows all of the material. Lecture notes are incredibly useful in understanding the subject. I did not think it was a particularly hard class, but how you do in GenChem depends heavily on your chemistry aptitude.

The best chemistry professor at NYU, hands down. You are provided with lecture notes that guide you through everything he teaches. Tests are based on things you learn from the notes. Every test has a section at the back for matching up terms and definitions, so be sure to study that. Full of self-deprecating jokes, and really knows his stuff.

I've had the privilege of having Prof. Halpin for CHEM UA 225 and UA 226, and he is a wonderful lecturer/Chem professor with clear grading criteria. Also seems to genuinely care about his students. Many opportunities to make up for your grade with the way his course is set up. Do the homework, attend lectures/read his notes, and you should do fine.

Halpin is an excellent professor but his exams are the hardest exams I have EVER taken. Even with studying I struggled but he is very knowledgable and if you work with him and your TA he will help you out. He is very fair and even drops one exam. I really enjoyed his class and I wish he taught another one because I came out so much smarter!

Halpin is great. He is course is very organized which is really helpful when your a freshmen or if you have a lot on your plate. going to lectures help because he explains things very well. the tests were hard, but he makes it really hard for you to do bad in the class because there are so many opportunities for you to bring your grade up.

Halpin is one of the friendliest professors at NYU and teaches chemistry in an enjoyable way. The tests are tough, but if you study you should be fine, because his grades are dependent on multiple factors (quizzes, lab, etc.) and he will even drop midterms :)
Probably the hottest teacher at NYU, hands down.

I found his lectures very, very helpful. I didn't have the opportunity to take Halpin for Gen. Chem. I and I had to basically learn all the information on my own from the textbook. Taking part II with Halpin was a relative blessing. He provides you with lecture notes that were constructed to help you follow along with nice meaty margins for notes.
Professor Halpin is the most straightforward teacher I've ever had. Truly a gem. The class has no curve but an A is very attainable if you pay attention to lectures and readings.
This guy is really good. He makes it so that you do great. I loved pte and recitation, it was so helpful. Lectures were kinda boring, but i like this dude. He is a cute little pumpkin.

Fantastic lecturer if you can stay awake through 8AM lectures. Though he provides notes, it's important to pay attention to actually understand what's in the the notes. Go to PTEs, recitations, and study with friends and you should be fine, but you definitely have to work for your grade. Drops low test scores with certain conditions (lifesaver!)

Halpin is one of the most competent professors at NYU! He knows his chemistry and is very picky. He drops in funny jokes here and there and makes it clear of what concepts will be on the tests. He strongly demands for correct number of sig figs. Tests are thorough and require studying. Recitation is fun and quizzes are easy. Overall a useful class.

He's good but, Chemistry is supposed to be taught as something beautiful. Unfortunately, the large class size makes that impossible. Also he has this silly rule where the only way you can drop your lowest test grade is if you score 50% better on your next test. So that means if you want a test grade dropped, make sure to fail it.

Halpin is an amazing prof! He really knows his stuff and can teach it well too. He made Gen Chem make sense. His tests are pretty straightforward, and he offers chances to drop low test grades. Would definitely recommend!
Great professor. Does everything he can to help you do well. Tests are sometimes tricky but, there is no reason not to do well. All of the resources are available you just have to use them

I thought he had a good sense of humour and was super nice.  His tests aren't easy, but they are definitely fair! I got an A in the course, so I was pretty happy.  He seems quite approachable and I know many of my friends visited his office hours.  I enjoyed his class (well, as much as one can enjoy gen chem!)
He will give you tips on how to pass his exams and quizzes.

No doubt he is one of the best professors at NYU, and maybe even in the country. His lecture notes are extremely clear, and he cares for his students. Gen chem is an essential foundation for advanced science courses, and he has done a fantastic job. Seems very strict but deep inside he's a very loving person.

Great lecturer. Everyone carries around his notes like they're the bible. Super clear during his lectures and very fair exams.  There's alot required (hw, quizzes, pte's, essays, attendance, exams) but if you do all of them, it only helps you learn the material and you should do well.

I saw him during office hours and he was really nice! He gives great lectures and I actually think his jokes are funny! Gen Chem is a hard class but it is totally possible to get an A in it if you work hard enough. Very fair grading system.

He is a very good professor with sense of humor.  I took his general chem II class. He doesn't use blackboard,and you have to take a lots of note during class. You have to finish all his homework problem, but the test isn't that hard. He gives partial credits,and extra credit question. Great to study chem with him. i missed his chem joke.

Very hard class and if you fall behind, you'd better work harder than you've ever worked before to catch up. However, his office hours are a great time to ask questions and really clarify anything you don't understand.

He's good at what he does. He loves chem, so it's good to see a professor who's truly and honestly passionate about the subject they teach the students. A very caring man, as long as you go to lectures and try to understand chemistry, you'll get it.
This guy is Papa Dio in Chemistry, take him at whatever cost, you would love the subject eventually.
Probably the clearest science teacher at NYU.

His test may be tricky at times but he always warns you on what to look out for in class. He isn't the friendliest or easiest teacher, but he is  fair and always stops the lectures to make sure he answers questions. He also breaks down the way you are going to be graded really well and is almost always available during office hours for extra help.

Prof. Halpin is a wonderful man. He really cares about his students and wants them to excel in the future, which is why he is so tough. His course is designed so that you must understand the material, not just memorize the book. And if you have any questions or concerns, his office hours are a great way to get things sorted out. He is always there

Halpin is an great professor who teaches well. Go to him whenever you need assistance with anything, really! He's very caring towards his students and sticks to what he says. A wonderful professor overall.

Halpin is an great professor who teaches well. Go to him whenever you need assistance with anything, really! He's very caring towards his students and always sticks to what he says. A wonderful professor overall.
amazing professor

Yes, it is a challenging course, but that's because Halpin genuinely wants you to understand the material. He is very fair and understanding. Do (and understand!) all the problems from the practice exam and you will be well prepared for his tests.

Professor Halpin is really the best. As a post-bacc student 8 years removed from college, and having never took any hard sciences before, I figured I'd really struggle. Struggle I did, but Prof. Halpin is very knowledgable, helpful during office hours, and his exams are tough but fair. The old exams from previous semesters are really helpful.

Halpin gets a bad reputation because he has the challenge of teaching 600+ students Chemistry at 8am on Mondays. But he is a genuinely kind person who understands that school is difficult and does his best to be clear, fair, and helpful.

Professor Halpin gives you every chance to succeed in his class as well as doing everything in his power to help you succeed. If you do the work and go see him for help (if you need it) there's no reason you shouldn't do well in this class. Plus, there really are no (or at least very few) surprises on his exams. ;) Very fair.

I took this class because I thought I wanted to be pre-med but that was a mistake.  However, I enjoyed John Halpin as a professor so much I contemplated staying on the pre-med track.  He really wants the students to learn the material and even though is voice is droning, he is an awesome person and professor!!
One of the best.
Awesome professor!
Great professor. Explains concepts well and provides many opportunities to bring up your grade such as easy online essays. Funny professor as well. Highly recommend

One of the best at NYU. If you're not doing well just go to him. He set me straight. Very fair. Know practice exams in and out. He sets up the course so that you can do well. Premeds this is the easiest it's going to be!
Definitely the best professor at NYU. Very clear, very helpful.
Great Teacger

Great professor. Very clear, and very straightforward, and although he sometimes speaks in a monotone he can also be pretty funny. He seems to not like the textbook very much, as he contradicts a lot of the things the book says. However, if you read his notes and explanations and do all the homework the class will be pretty easy.

Prof. Halpin is easily my favorite professor so far in NYU. His style of teaching is over 9000. As long as you read his lecture notes and do the practice exams, you can easily score at least an A- on his exam. In fact, the practice exams are particularly the exact same thing as the actual exams. HALPIN really knows what he's talking about!

Absolutely amazing. I feel like he'll be the best professor I'll have in my college career. He explains everything in his lectures perfectly, and his notes help soo much. He's a really cool guy too. His class wasn't the easiest, but like he says, it's possible for everyone to get an A. People who didn't just didn't connect somehow.

Once you get used to the class, his jokes become a thousand times funnier. Exams are difficult but fair. Three exams, a lab final, and mandated extra help for at least seven hours per semester. Weekly quizzes are annoying, but really do help. Overall a pretty great HS-to-college-transition professor!!

Halpin will do everything that he can to help you, but in the most efficient way. He wants you to do well and thus CHALLENGES you to think for yourself, seems like he cares about his students. Great professor, fair, knows his stuff, very straightforward. Love the fact that he has lecture notes and cracks a joke every now and then
Great teacher; easily the best in the whole science department. Has a clear love for his job!
Amazing professor especially for chemistry. Helpful and funny. Just wants to see an effort from students and grading reflects that.

Lectures were rather boring, didn't help me at all.  Recitations were great if you have the right TA. You get easy points just for showing up to PTE, and the worksheets are extremely helpful.  Overall, Halpin is a teacher before a chemist, if you struggle, go have a talk with him and he'll do his best to help you out and give you a fair grade.

I really enjoyed his class. If you need help, go to him after lecture and he will more than willingly help you. Also the TA's are spectacular! Along with everyone being really helpful and actually wanting you to succeed, they grade every test withing one weekend! That's effieciancy.

Great professor, AMAZING chef. Even though the lecture size is over 700 students, he sometimes brings homemade snacks for everybody. His baklava is to die for!! Betty's "Food Writing" class was most definitely my favorite class this semester. She is not only informative and incredibly helpful, but also really fun and enthusiastic. I'd 10/10 recommend.

Betty is such a great professor, she is not like a regular professor that teaches you things you will never need in life, she actually teaches you life skills. awesome personality, fun, extremely kind and just the best. Betty is the Best! This is why journalism classes exist. She is always available and is dedicated to cultivating your skills as a reporter, and human being. highly recommended.

Thanks!

i learned a lot.
